Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Is richer always better? Testing the biotic resistance hypothesis in ornamental fish microbiomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The sum of microorganisms living on and in a host is called the "microbiome". A host's microbiome often has more cells and functions than the host itself, and plays important roles in nutrition, health and disease. Antibiotic treatment disrupts microbiomes in mice and humans and increases the likelihood of bacterial infections after treatment. Fish depend on their microbiome and are often treated with antibiotics in commercial settings, particularly along ornamental trade routes where suppliers must deliver a disease-free product to retail pet shops. This study will test if antibiotics have the unintended consequence of disturbing fish microbiomes during shipment, thereby reducing disease resistance after fish have arrived in retail store tanks. The researchers will collaborate with the Woods Hole Partnership in Education Program to involve underrepresented groups in the laboratory research. Additionally, the researchers will continue ongoing collaborations with ornamental fish industry members, engaging the private sector in science-based solutions to disease. This research will provide valuable insight into the role microbiomes play in aquaculture diseases and potential probiotic treatments, and contribute to the advancement of science-based solutions to aquaculture development.

A reduction in biotic resistance, or the ability to protect the host from colonization and
proliferation of external pathogens, often accompanies antibiotic treatments. The first aim of this research is to assess the influence of antibiotics on disease resistance in fish microbiomes, using aquarium-based experiments in the laboratory. Ornamental fish shipments with and without the use of antibiotics will be simulated, followed by a spike of a known fish pathogen. Biotic resistance will be measured by mortality, and the relative abundance of the spiked pathogen within fish microbiomes. In humans and mouse models, re-inoculation after antibiotic treatment with a high-richness microbial community restores biotic resistance. The second objective of this research will be to test a range of bacterial inoculates for their ability to restore biotic resistance in fish microbiomes after antibiotic treatment. These inoculates will vary in their richness and composition, and biotic resistance will be assessed as above, alongside resulting microbiome richness. The researchers will test the hypothesis that a low-richness recovery inoculum of probiotic species representing a variety of disease resistance mechanisms will provide the strongest possible microbiome-mediated biotic resistance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sum of microorganisms living on and in a host is called the ‘microbiome’. A host’s microbiome often has more cells and functions than the host itself and plays important roles in nutrition, health and disease. Antibiotic treatment disrupts microbiomes in mice and humans and increases the likelihood of bacterial infections after treatment. Fish also depend on their microbiome and are often treated with antibiotics in commercial settings, particularly in aquaculture and along ornamental trade routes where suppliers must deliver a disease-free product via stressful international shipping routes to retail pet shops. 

The goals of this study were to understand how prophylactic antibiotic use may impact downstream disease resistance by impacting the fish microbiome. Although antibiotic treatments clearly have short term benefits, including the delivery of a pathogen-free fish after shipment or removal of a bacterial pathogen from a tank, their long term costs have not been explored. The first objective of this project was therefore to assess this cost by determining any increases to disease susceptibility after prophylactic antibiotic treatment. This project was also able to test the idea that beneficial bacteria, or ‘probiotics’, can restore the function of the fish microbiome, and reverse any negative impacts of antibiotics on downstream disease resistance.

By executing a carefully planned experimental design using a popular ornamental fish, and using the latest molecular and bioinformatics technologies, this project was able to collect data to address both of our hypotheses. Our results show that antibiotics do in fact reduce disease resistance of fish, as shown by the higher mortality in ‘antibiotic only’ treatments. Most interestingly, however, our results also show that the probiotic species we administered reverses this negative effect, as shown by the ‘antibiotics + probiotics’ treatment (Figure 1).

The work completed by this proposal has broader impacts both within and outside of the scientific community. Our results provide interesting insight to the scientific community regarding a long-standing debate about the role of community composition and diversity on microbiome function. By clearly demonstrating that colonization of probiotics into fish microbiomes does not alter community richness, but does increase disease resistance, our results highlight the importance of composition (“who’s there”) over richness (“biodiversity”) for microbiome functionality.

Our results also have broad implications for the ornamental and food fish aquaculture industries. We show that long-term costs of increased mortality must be considered by farmers hoping to reduce pathogen loads during shipment of ornamental fish. We further show that when antibiotic treatments are necessary, in the case of a farm wide disease outbreak for example, application of probiotics after antibiotic treatment is one way to reduce long term reductions in disease resistance.

Finally, this project also supported the training of two undergraduate researchers and the dissertation research of one Ph.D. candidate. The project resulted in two subsequent grant applications based on initial results, two scientific conference presentations, and one manuscript in the final stages of preparation for submission.
